I think we can tease out some valid claims in the article that should be addressed. He's telling a story about a society that is sick and implicit is a claim about the malleability of human nature as an answer to the question why we are violent. If there are no inborn violent impulses or they can be changed radically then it must be passed on to us through culture, hence this idea that violence has become sacred, that it isn't open to question through some kind of cultural process. If we avail ourselves of the evidence in relevant fields it doesn't take much effort to see that this is mistaken. Does that mean we can't become more humane or well behaved? Of course not The thesis of Pinker's book that we can and have made progress despite this inherited propensity for violence.

The other part of the story is that violence is inherent to the neoliberal order, that the hegemony of violent western states has blinded us to the violence surrounding us. There's far too much contradictory evidence for that to be a serious theory of the history of violence in the 20th century. That doesn't imply that we shouldn't be concerned with the history of imperialism, colonialism, and slavery, including recent failures in liberal interventionism, in the course of determining the world we want and what we should do about it; but it's a feeble answer to the question of why we are violent and simplistic in its diagnosis of what to do about international order.

This call for poetry undercuts itself with a lack of it. The "spectacle" is an overdone meme. In a world with too much violence, too often serving undeserved power, still there are true evils which need killing. If the argument is to be for thorough pacifism, make it plainly. Don't just pose questions implying that pacifism's the answer the teacher wants, without going through the steps to coherently argue for its practicality or wisdom, let alone the dance which might establish the poetry of such a dream.
Can we make the payload nuclear waste? That would solve another problem and allow us to add nuclear back in to the base power production, with solar and wind responding to demand increases.

Putting a launch site up north, away from the equator doesn't really make any sense.    The main US one is down in Florida because it's hard to get further south without leaving the country (plus it has oceans to the east to dispose of failures relatively safely).

No, launching nuclear waste into space would be (a) expensive (b) have people freaking out about safety (c) it would be a waste, because "waste" isn't really waste if you can recycle it, and we can. Keeping it in dry cask storage at the plant sites is okay for the immediate future, and we can use it as fuel in fourth generation nuclear power plants.

The main obstacles to nuclear are (1) we have a warped energy market where fossil fuels are not charged for dumping poison in the atmosphere (2) psychological: the anti-nuclear fanatics have done an excellent job of demonizing a power source that's on average extremely safe and clean.

No more prisons would be good. Of course it would require no more crime. One of the things that contributes to the existence of crime is the repetition of the apparent indifference to human suffering that would seem to be embodied in criminal acts. It would seem that it is particularly true when it is imposed by the authority figures in a supposedly civilized society. We need to protect ourselves. No question. But you are only confirming that the behavior will continue when you demonstrate that it is culturally acceptable.

This is exactly what people need to understand. Extended periods of solitary confinement can drive a man insane. I'm for 4-5 month sentences to the SHU, but assigning someone to 7  years of 23 hour lockdown is a totally different story.

I have been volunteering for over 11 years in correction facilities in Washington State for Muslim inmates, leading congregational (Jummah) prayers, teaching, counseling, occasionally performing Islamic marriage. The vast majority of those inmates embraced Islam within the prison system. In the last two years, I have been volunteering as needed in a maximum penitentiary. Some of them spend over twenty hours a day in solitary confinement. To me, as a physician and a practicing Muslim, I look at them as wonderful people who have been reformed. I highly trust them. When they get out of prison, my major concern is going back to the environment they left behind. Many of those inmates came from broken families, which is unfortunately common in the United States. I always feel that the real problem we are facing in this country is not terrorism -- though it should be contained and dealt with. It is family dislocation, low morality, addiction to alcohol and street drugs. I encourage those Muslim inmates to read and get involved with learning, as they have plenty of time. I remind them of the smallest chapter in the Holy Qur’an – 103, As Almighty God swears, “By the time! Man is in a state of loss; save those who have faith and do righteous deeds and exhort one another to the truth and abide by patience and perseverance.” Time is the most important thing in life. It goes so fast and has to be used wisely. It will never be recaptured again.

The SHU facilities are maintained to keep jobs for the people in upstate NY and probably elsewhere. The stock holders are the ones making big money as well. This , mostly every inmate knows about. Solitary confinement makes an inmate worse and needs to be fixed asap.

And the last 6 mentioned the inmate never see's.  I've said it before , SHU stays in business for the sake of correctional jobs. Where else are these people in the boondocks going to work? No sympathy here, they make $25..00 an hour to sit in a bubble.

"There's no such thing as a bad boy." Father Flannigan. There is good and evil in the world.

Yes they are. But that part of what prisons are supposed to be and do has not started yet, we have to wait until all the baddies are in jail before starting the process of rehabilitation, otherwise they will miss out!

And that wouldn't be fair would it?

D's comment reflects the prison administration mindset:  punish, punish, punish. Punish exclusively, don't teach inmates lifeskills.  Be nasty.  What kind of results do you get from treating inmates poorly?  You get bad behavior, not good behavior. The research that establishes punishment is a poor way of changing behavior is voluminous.   It is suggested by D. we not give mundane tools to inmates to learn how to function in society.  So you want to release them without knowing how to function in society?  Keep them from learning how to look for a job (via a computer)?   Don't tell them how to use the metro system with it's magnetic cards?  Keep them thinking they should buy tokens for the subway when they get released?  And while you can get SHU time for a major offense, you can get SHU time for having more than the regulation number of postage stamps (6),   or asking your minister back home for some money so you can buy a box of tissues (I know an inmate who got 9 months solitary for that one).  Policies in prison should make sense, not nonsense.

To (1) I'll add (if only we could edit comments!) after "both direct and indirect", short term, medium term, and long term, taking into account all important factors, like how hard it is to recover from the bad from one option versus another.

Really, when the basics of cost-benefit analysis are missing from even the analyses and decisions of some influential economists -- where smart cost-benefit analysis is the essence of good economics -- we have a lot of educational work to do.

Crucial concepts to teach (should really be stressed in college, and K-12):

1) Cost-benefit analysis -- So, so often, and from influential people you see cost only analysis, or benefit only analysis, instead of a careful weighing of all of the significant costs and benefits, both direct and indirect, or at least some brief indication that that's what you've done (and no, often it looks it's not that they have, and it's just not coming out that way for brevity).

2) "I think this was an ex ante mistake even if it turns out OK ex post". How often do you hear the expression no harm, no foul, as a justification that it was a good, or fine, decision.

Aw, c'mon.  Lighten up.  I don't see any "hysteria" or "rage" in these reasonable comments.  And of course caring about one's puzzling streak is a bit silly.  But what's wrong with some silliness as a harmless diversion from everyday stresses?

I love the hysteria over the typo and people's rage at having their night ruined and having to wait a whole day or two to have their perfection re-unblemished (albeit forever asterisked, in my book).  Reminds me of my two favorite songs:  "Cry Me a River" and "Schadenfreude."

And that's the big difference between now and yesterday.  I was shocked when i saw the video games my young male students were 'playing'.  Killing games are common pleasures for them.  It gives them an adrenaline rush.  Too bad young men don't have healthier ways to unleash this energy.

Never before in history have humans been able to simulate violence so realistically. We can initiate violent experiences on demand, without moral or physical consequences. We can watch it passively on television or engage in it directly through simulations, all in the privacy of our own homes. Alternatively, we can immerse ourselves in real violence occurring anywhere in the world through a dozen sources at once. The real world may actually be less physically violent by many statistical measures. Our inner world however, is probably more intensely violent than ever. We think we can control it with an on and off switch. Perhaps this is why we have deluded ourselves into thinking that it's possible to conduct antiseptic war by remote control, without any pain or sacrifice.

Why do you have to use insults like "head in the sand"?

Rape is underreported everywhere including India and the US. To know the correct numbers we need to know the correction factors which we do not actually know. It could well be that after the correction factors are applied in both cases, the rate in the US (or Sweden) will still be higher than in India. We cannot JUST go by our prejudice against an "Area of Darkness."

And of course we CAN learn from other nations including the West. Aren't you and I discussing this in English rather than in Hindi or Sanskrit?

But the West is extremely reluctant that any learning go in the opposite direction.

For instance Indian Epistemology flourished between the 3rd and 17th century long before comparable developments in the West. (And no, this is not an "India is always best" Hindutva argument but based on sources).

We have to judge ourselves when we CAN learn from the West and when we CANNOT.

For instance America needs to pay better attention to why it is that Indian Americans are better educated and have higher incomes than all groups including whites. Could it be that there is something GOOD about Indian civilization?
